{{expansion}}{{disambig-more: '''''The Hobbit''''' (also known as '''The Hobbit Software Adventure''' in North America and [[Australia]]) was the first licensed video game based on Tolkien's work, being the first part of ''[[The Tolkien Trilogy]]'' (also known as ''[[The Tolkien Software Adventure Series]]''). The game was designed by [[Philip Mitchell]] and [[Veronika Megler]],<ref name="world spectrum"/> and illustrated by Kent Rees.<ref name="Review p. 76">{{webcite
column7: accessed=23-Dec-2011}}</ref> The game was considered large at the time of its release and included  80 locations, of which 30 were illustrated.<ref name="Review p. 76"/> The game was released by [[Melbourne House]] for [[wikipedia:Amstrad CPC
column14: ZX-Spectrum]] in most of the world,<ref name="Tolkien Games">{{webcite
column17: articlename=The Hobbit / The Hobbit Software Adventure
column20: accessed=30 december 2014}}</ref> whilst [[Addison-Wesley]] released it as ''The Hobbit Software Adventure'' for [[wikipedia:Apple II
column24: MS-DOS]] in North America and Australia.<ref name="Tolkien Games"/> After its initial success, it was re-released by Sinclair Research Ltd.<ref name="world spectrum"/> Beam Software also developed editions for [[wikipedia:Amiga
column26: TRS-80]], <!-- and MVS ?? --> but were never released.<ref name="Tolkien Games"/> Every game also included a copy of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' and an instruction book.<ref name="Review p. 76"/>
